author: jgm
content: I think the Ethereum community needs to reconsider if they want to trust the relay totally, or a half-way house may be better.  A possible solution would be for the current https://ethereum.github.io/builder-specs/#/Builder/submitBlindedBlock endpoint to be tweaked so that it only requires a signed beacon block header.  This would leave the ultimate decision as to if to publish a block or not to be down to the proposer, which could decide based upon the transactions list that it obtains as the return from this call.  So if, for example, the proposer believes that the block does not contain transactions that it would expect to see it can reject the block (although unfortunately not propose another block instead, due to already making the signed header public).

author: jlokier
content:
>  So if, for example, the proposer believes that the block does not contain transactions that it would expect to see

I've been thinking about how we may be able to use ZK in future to prove that a builder has selected a reasonably fair selection of the transactions known to exist on the network, without necessarily revealing all of the builder's algorithm or knowledge.  This would prevent gross distortions such as transactions that most nodes can see but are consistently being omitted because they don't have an MEV backhander code or something.

author: jlokier
content: The purpose of this idea is to improve fairness of inclusion on the network for all participants proposing their own transactions which other nodes can see shared in the pool.  The effect would be to reduce distortion due to MEV and "who you know".

author: jgm
content:
Always hearing about this attack, but it requires a relatively large player to be able to carry out, and even then they will have the ability to do so relatively infrequently.  How many players could conceivably pull this off given the current validator distribution (I don't see collusion happening due to the risk of one of the partners being a whistleblower)?  Two?  Three?  And we know who they are.

These entities will also need to have a system that will allow them to quickly take a block apart to see what MEV opportunities are in it, calculate their relative value, be able to craft additional transactions to extract the MEV themselves, and balance that against whatever additional MEV they may obtain in the second block if they do accept the first block.  Plus, they will lose the entire block reward from the first block (both consensus and execution) so the actuality of it being worthwhile seems incredibly low to me.  And of course the relay will be able to publish the block header to show that the proposer received transactions for the first block but didn't broadcast them, which would put the onus on the proposer to explain why they did not broadcast the block (and the proposer, being a validator, has a stake that could be socially slashed if the explanation does not hold up to scrutiny).
